instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

threads.title: 820-3662 Random shutdown part 9999
threads.message:
So I've been reading about the shutdown problems of the 2013-2014 models. 3 possible solutions are suggested by the internet:
1) Removing the kext responsible for ethernet over thunderbolt
2) Using the nocrashmbp utility made by RealMacMods
3) Replacing the VCORE driver FDMF6808 for a 6708. 

Number 2 and 3 seem to address a similar root cause of entering faulty power state. Number 1 does not seem to be related (?), but fixes the problem for a lot of users.

Questions:
1) Are we looking at 1 single problem or are things being confused on the internet?
2) Do we know the root cause(s) and how to differentiate between them?
3) VCORE driver replacement seems to be the way to go for a 820-3662 with random shutdowns. Agree?
4) Which board are affected by this problem / these problems?

threads.title: 820-3662 Random shutdown part 9999
threads.message: Is this integrated graphics or dedicated graphics? It seems the integrated is more likely to work replacing the FDMF chips. The dual graphics not as much. According to Duke, it's def an issue with the fets tho. Seems like the dual graphics also get CPU issues from flexion not just the fets.

threads.title: 820-3662 Random shutdown part 9999
threads.message: I have had 3 units 820-3662 with this issue, all fixed after replacing FDMF IC's.

threads.title: 820-3662 Random shutdown part 9999
threads.message: Late update: fixed with new FDMF drivers.Thanks guys!
